Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 18. The Bodhisattva Renounces Home
The Bodhisattva said, "This night is the last That I will lie at home with a woman. From this day forth, at home with a woman I will not lie together."
Tired from singing, dancing, and making music, the women fell asleep. He saw them with disheveled hair, strewn about naked, drooling, and mumbling. He found them all repulsive.
Meanwhile, Prajapati dreamed the moon was eclipsed, the sun rose and then set in the east, and that many people bowed to him as she cried and was upset.

Sun of Faith - English: Yashodhara had eight dreams. Her house beams splintered. Her bed cracked. Her bangles broke. Her teeth fell out. Her braids fell apart. The status of her house faded. The planets eclipsed the moon. And the sun set in the east.

The Bodhisattva had five dreams. Mount Meru was his pillow, and the earth his bed. His right hand touched the western ocean, and his left the eastern ocean. His feet reached the depths of the great ocean. A long stalk of grass called "the upright" grew from his navel and rose into the sky. Many birds with white bodies and black heads touched his feet and licked them. Various sorts of birds came from every direction, gathered in the presence of his body, and changed into a single color. And he walked upon a mountain of impure substances yet was unsulied by any impurities.
The Bodhisattva was filled with joy and he thought, "With dreams such as I have had, before long I will attain unsurpassed wisdom."

When Yashodhara recounted her dreams, he told her that they were untrue so as to dispell her ill feeling. Then the Bodhisattva thought, "Without a doubt, I must depart for the wilderness. I will indicate this to her indirectly." So he just hinted to Yashodhara about this.

"Divine One, take me with you wherever you go!" said Yashodhara. And as the Bodhisattva reflected upon the nature of tranquility, he promised her, "I will do so." All told, he had lived in the court for twenty-nine years.
The gods such as Indra and Brahma knew the Bodhisattva's intentions. Realizing it was time for his renunciation, they asked him to rise up and urged him to depart for the wilderness.
"How can I," the Bodhisattva asked, "when the army has surrounded the palace?"
Indra replied,"You will be unhindered, As you journey to the wildnerness. Brahma, the other gods, and I, Will make the journey as well." Delighted, the Bodhisattva rose.
Then Indra overpowered the people with sleep.
The yaksha Panchika lifted up the giant ladder which had required five hundred men to move. The Bodhisattva descended the ladder and reached bottom.
He woke the sleeping Chandaka, and said "Go get my horse Kanthaka. I am going to the wilderness!"
Chandaka replied, "Divine One, it is not time for the pleasure gardens. Not even a few bear you ill will and no one is your enemy. Why do you ride off in the middle of the night?
"Do not disregard my words," said the Bodhisattva. "I am affraid of the dark," replied Chandaka, and he did not get the horse. They argued back and forth about getting the horse.

The Bodhisattva thought the people would be roused and he went to fetch Kanthaka himself. The horse was aware that the Bodhisattva was going to the forest of austeries. Unsettled, he pulled away, contorting and rearing his feet. The Bodhisattva slowly brought his hand to Kanthaka's head.

"Kanthaka, take this final burden. Take me to the forest of austerities. I will reach enlightement, and quickly Shower people with meditation and liberation." In this way he calmed the horse and saddled him.

Then Indra arranged for the four divine heros—Tira, Upatira, Parna, and Parnaparidhita—to transport them. The Bodhisattva asked about their strength. Indra gradually explained how they were able to lift up and carry the earth, the four great oceans, and all the earth's mountains, grasses and trees.

The Bodhisattva placed his foot on the ground and exerted themselves but could not move him. And so they were filled with wonder. Seeing and hearing this, Chandaka was also filled with wonder, and came forward. The Bodhisattva mounted Kanthaka, and Chandaka jumped on behind him. Powered by the gods, Kanthaka rose into the sky above. The gods who remained in the palace wept.

"If I were to leave through any other gate," the youth thought, "It would break my father's heart if he thought that he had not seen me a final time." So he went to King Shuddhodana at the eastern gate. But Suddhodana was laid out in a deep sleep, and was not aware of him.
"I mean no disrespect," the Bodhisattva said to his father. "I intend to liberate all beings in the world from suffering."
Then Mahanaman saw what had happened. With tears in his eyes he said, "O Youth, this is not the right way!"

"Mahanaman," said the Bodhisattva "If I have cultivated enlightnement for the sake of sentient beings by means of many austerities throughout three incalculable eons, why would I now stay home? This much is certain, I will go to the wilderness to practice austerities."
His words were so powerful that Mahanama was unable to repeat his request."Today King Shuddhodana, And all of the Shakya people, Who have wished again and again, Have had their hopes bear no fruit."

Wailing in this way, Mahanaman tried to wake up Yashodhara and the others. But they would not wake up. He called out to King Shuddhodana, but he would not rise from his sleep. He shouted in every direction, but it was as if he was calling out into the desolate wilderness. No one would wake up, and there was no reply at all.

Then the four divine heroes lifted the Bodhisattva by the four hooves of his horse. The gods of the Form Realm were chastened to proper behavior, and departed to the right. The gods of the Desire Realm held aloft many offerings, and departed to the left. Brahma and Indra naturally acted appropriately, and departed at the front of the Bodhisattva's horse. From an opening in heavens above, the gods played music, let fall a rain of flowers, and gave various offerings.
Inscription - English: The four gods lifted the horse's four hooves, and lifting them, flew out across the sky.

Sun of Faith - English: Then the Bodhisattva said to the gods, "Excellent." The gods in turn requested, "Bodhisattva, when you attain unexcelled enlightement, think of us." The Bodhisattva promised to do so.
